awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Standard:  Comparison of Communications across Campus Cultures  (4C Project): Toward Evidence-based Customization of Learning Experiences for CCE STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Ethical behavior of STEM professionals is essential for the progress of science, advancement of the national health, and prosperity and welfare. Therefore STEM trainees must receive the appropriate education to mature into responsible professionals that display an awareness and understanding of ethical challenges within STEM. Does "one size fits all" STEM ethics training result in a well-trained STEM workforce?
The goal of this collaborative project is to define, through data, STEM ethics learning communities and then develop a strategy for matching communities with resources effective for them. Through this study, hundreds of STEM trainees from four distinct higher learning institutions will each provide individual demographic and academic information, survey data, and writing samples. The data sets generated will be analyzed to determine which common qualities define ethical STEM learning communities. Evidence-based identification of learning communities will then provide the basis for strategically matching them with a subset of the many resources and experiences already developed for ethical STEM education. This study will be conducted simultaneously at campuses with different constituencies and cultures: (1) Saint Mary's College, an all-women's college; (2) the University of Notre Dame, a Catholic research university; (3) Xavier University, a Historically Black College or University (HBCU); and (4) the University of Virginia, a public research university. 

The methods employed will include administration and analysis of five validated scales (for learning style, personality, moral concern, moral action, and environmental orientation) and automated text analysis of student writings in three different formats (electronic journal entry, online discussion forum, and Twitter). To develop and test principles of differentiated instruction emerging from this research, investigators from each institution will design and offer pilot learning experiences combining a single established resource or approach for ethics education with one defined learning community. The resulting case reports and underlying principles are expected to be articulated in the Strategic Engagement of Learning Communities for Ethical STEM Handbook and distributed across STEM research networks, the science and engineering ethics community, informal science and education networks, and K-12 science education networks.

por.por_cntn:
Because science and engineering affects everyone in society, science and engineering students should gain experience addressing the moral and ethical aspects of the work that they do. There are many open questions about how to best approach ethics learning for STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) students. Techniques that are effective for learning about the objective and technical aspects of these fields are not compatible with some important aspects of ethics learning, as questions regarding moral issues are more nuanced and subjective.  Our project is concerned with ethics education about broad and complex matters that arise where science and technology interact with society at large.  We hypothesized that STEM ethics learning is personal, in that it is important to understand individual perspectives (where someone is coming from) to meet students where they are and promote holistic learning and development. 

When we started our project, little was known about some of the similarities and differences among STEM learners that are likely to be relevant for ethics learning.  We postulated that factors such as personality, personal and societal level moral values, and attitudes towards the natural environment might play an important role in how students respond to ethics education. To investigate this, we conducted a multi-component survey that included questions from the Big Five Personality Index (BFI), the New Environmental Paradigm (NEP), the Moral Foundations Questionnaire (MFQ), the Values in Action (VIA), and the ASSIST Learning Style assessment.  

 

We collected data from 659 STEM students at four different US universities: The University of Notre Dame, University of Virginia, Saint Mary's College, and Xavier University of Louisiana over four years.  The survey captured data about each student's major/program of study, gender, race/ethnicity, religious affiliation and practice, prior formal ethics learning, and more.  The most important finding from our survey research about STEM learners is that there is far more diversity within any group defined by a commonality (such as major/program of study, gender, race/ethnicity, or religion) than between different groups.  This is important because it shows that educators should not make assumptions about a starting point for ethics learning based on a student's major/program of study, their gender, or other group-identifier. 

 

Our project also addressed an additional gap in the field of STEM ethics learning.  While the educational value of reflective writing in response to assigned prompts has been recognized by other fields, such as medical education, the responses of science and engineering students have not been well studied.  By coordinating assignments with different educators at the previously mentioned universities, our research addressed the way individuals responded to the same open-ended questions, at the same time, in online discussion with one another.  This approach connected learners from different majors at different universities and allowed for the exploration of STEM ethics in societal context through real-life examples.  For example, online discussion facilitated thoughtful consideration and interaction about the soaring price of Epi-Pens as the phenomenon was in the news.  To learn all we could from what the students wrote, a team of researchers used a systematic approach to record data about specific ideas and themes expressed.  One of the most important things we found is that students recognize that the experience of online reflective writing in discussion with others led to learning about STEM ethics, and in some cases, led to a fundamental shift in students' understanding of what ethics means in the context of science and engineering practice.  This project provided the proof-of-concept by using prompts for reflective writing that was facilitated in an online discussion with peers. This approach will be sustained by the Online Ethics Center for Engineering and Science.  Our findings about ethics learning through reflective writing in online discussion will be reported to scholars in the STEM ethics education field through a full-length research manuscript that is accepted, pending revisions in the Journal of Science and Engineering Ethics.

 

Our project has directly involved undergraduate and graduate students from the four different universities involved, including four undergraduate University of Virginia students, two Indiana University students, two Saint Mary's College students, and one Xavier University student, advancing their training as researchers, professionals, and practitioners prepared to lead future exploration of ethics in the context of STEM.
